        I'm still having difficulty reproducing this in a stable, debuggable way. To summarize findings so far:<span class="line"><!---->I'm still having difficulty reproducing this in a stable, debuggable way. To summarize findings so far:<!----></span><br><br>- There appear to be two different crashes, see the backtraces in <span class="line"><!---->- There appear to be two different crashes, see the backtraces in <!----></span>#c15<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c15"><!---->#c15<!----></a> (crash in irregexp) and in <span class="line"><!----> (crash in irregexp) and in <!----></span>#c14<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c14"><!---->#c14<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>#c16<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c16"><!---->#c16<!----></a> (something else). I've only investigated the former in this bug report.<span class="line"><!----> (something else). I've only investigated the former in this bug report.<!----></span><br>- Crashes are reproduced by clicking HavTest and refreshing. Sometimes the crash seems to reproduce easily, at other times it can take many attempts. Due to memory pressure? Due to cache states? It seems to help to change window focus before refreshing the page.<span class="line"><!---->- Crashes are reproduced by clicking HavTest and refreshing. Sometimes the crash seems to reproduce easily, at other times it can take many attempts. Due to memory pressure? Due to cache states? It seems to help to change window focus before refreshing the page.<!----></span><br>- I attempted to bisect but the crash is too flaky.<span class="line"><!---->- I attempted to bisect but the crash is too flaky.<!----></span><br>- The symptoms quite clearly point at a problem with the regexp bytecode array or regexp interpreter dispatch, specifically dispatch seems to jump to an invalid address (we use the computed goto extension for interpreter dispatch).<span class="line"><!---->- The symptoms quite clearly point at a problem with the regexp bytecode array or regexp interpreter dispatch, specifically dispatch seems to jump to an invalid address (we use the computed goto extension for interpreter dispatch).<!----></span><br>- This can happen either because the read bytecode is invalid (the bytecode array may be corrupted, may have moved, we may read OOB, or may not be a bytecode array at all); or because ASAN somehow interferes with the computed goto extension. The latter is not an academic possibility, we've seen crashes related due to addtl requirements on registers from ASAN in the past.<span class="line"><!---->- This can happen either because the read bytecode is invalid (the bytecode array may be corrupted, may have moved, we may read OOB, or may not be a bytecode array at all); or because ASAN somehow interferes with the computed goto extension. The latter is not an academic possibility, we've seen crashes related due to addtl requirements on registers from ASAN in the past.<!----></span><br>- Unfortunately I haven't managed to debug this properly yet. On my linux laptop, I get neither an ASAN report, nor does gdb break on the segv. On my Windows VM, after jumping through many hoops, I do get symbolized ASAN reports - but the crash is super-flaky and I know nothing about debugging chromium with windbg. Plus the VM is severely resource-constrained and I can't compile custom builds there.<span class="line"><!---->- Unfortunately I haven't managed to debug this properly yet. On my linux laptop, I get neither an ASAN report, nor does gdb break on the segv. On my Windows VM, after jumping through many hoops, I do get symbolized ASAN reports - but the crash is super-flaky and I know nothing about debugging chromium with windbg. Plus the VM is severely resource-constrained and I can't compile custom builds there.<!----></span><br>- Next steps: attempt to repro on a non-ASAN build.<span class="line"><!---->- Next steps: attempt to repro on a non-ASAN build.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Tracing isolate creation and flag values suggests something is altering flag values after the Isolate has started:<span class="line"><!---->Tracing isolate creation and flag values suggests something is altering flag values after the Isolate has started:<!----></span><br><br>Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e2b10 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e2b10 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e24d0 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e24d0 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x7fe744008d50 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x7fe744008d50 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x7fe70800d570 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x7fe70800d570 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<!----></span><br>[...]<span class="line"><!---->[...]<!----></span><br>isolate 0x55614d0e2b10  // Immediately prior to the DCHECK failure.<span class="line"><!---->isolate 0x55614d0e2b10  // Immediately prior to the DCHECK failure.<!----></span><br><br>Note isolate 0x55614d0e2b10 starts with --regexp-interpret-all unset but has the flag set prior to the crash.<span class="line"><!---->Note isolate 0x55614d0e2b10 starts with --regexp-interpret-all unset but has the flag set prior to the crash.<!----></span><br><br>It looks like chrome is misusing V8 by starting multiple isolates with different jitless configs in the same process. I vaguely recall hearing related chatter in recent months, gotta do some research.<span class="line"><!---->It looks like chrome is misusing V8 by starting multiple isolates with different jitless configs in the same process. I vaguely recall hearing related chatter in recent months, gotta do some research.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        #38: Thanks, that confirms my suspicions. Since v8 flags are process-wide, it's not valid to spawn multiple isolates with different flags in the same process. For --jitless and friends (e.g. --regexp-interpret-all) it's especially problematic. I suspect the second bug report with different symptoms (<span class="line"><!---->#38: Thanks, that confirms my suspicions. Since v8 flags are process-wide, it's not valid to spawn multiple isolates with different flags in the same process. For --jitless and friends (e.g. --regexp-interpret-all) it's especially problematic. I suspect the second bug report with different symptoms (<!----></span>crbug.com/1264813<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1264813" title="AddressSanitizer: access-violation on unknown address 0x7ed000084040"><!---->crbug.com/1264813<!----></a>) may have the same root cause.<span class="line"><!---->) may have the same root cause.<!----></span><br><br>1) Since SharedStorageAPI is *not* on by default, there is currently no direct user-visible impact.<span class="line"><!---->1) Since SharedStorageAPI is *not* on by default, there is currently no direct user-visible impact.<!----></span><br><br>2) SharedStorageAPI is currently spawns V8 isolates in a way that interferes with other V8 isolates in the same renderer process and will lead to all kinds of hard-to-debug followup errors. The solution is to not spawn SharedStorageAPI isolates with custom flags (-> remove --jitless).<span class="line"><!---->2) SharedStorageAPI is currently spawns V8 isolates in a way that interferes with other V8 isolates in the same renderer process and will lead to all kinds of hard-to-debug followup errors. The solution is to not spawn SharedStorageAPI isolates with custom flags (-&gt; remove --jitless).<!----></span><br><br>3) For the V8 side, two potential work items are in <span class="line"><!---->3) For the V8 side, two potential work items are in <!----></span>#c34<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c34"><!---->#c34<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>yaoxia@ I'm reassigning to you for point 2) above.<span class="line"><!---->yaoxia@ I'm reassigning to you for point 2) above.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I'm still having difficulty reproducing this in a stable, debuggable way. To summarize findings so far:<span class="line"><!---->I'm still having difficulty reproducing this in a stable, debuggable way. To summarize findings so far:<!----></span><br><br>- There appear to be two different crashes, see the backtraces in <span class="line"><!---->- There appear to be two different crashes, see the backtraces in <!----></span>#c15<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c15"><!---->#c15<!----></a> (crash in irregexp) and in <span class="line"><!----> (crash in irregexp) and in <!----></span>#c14<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c14"><!---->#c14<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>#c16<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c16"><!---->#c16<!----></a> (something else). I've only investigated the former in this bug report.<span class="line"><!----> (something else). I've only investigated the former in this bug report.<!----></span><br>- Crashes are reproduced by clicking HavTest and refreshing. Sometimes the crash seems to reproduce easily, at other times it can take many attempts. Due to memory pressure? Due to cache states? It seems to help to change window focus before refreshing the page.<span class="line"><!---->- Crashes are reproduced by clicking HavTest and refreshing. Sometimes the crash seems to reproduce easily, at other times it can take many attempts. Due to memory pressure? Due to cache states? It seems to help to change window focus before refreshing the page.<!----></span><br>- I attempted to bisect but the crash is too flaky.<span class="line"><!---->- I attempted to bisect but the crash is too flaky.<!----></span><br>- The symptoms quite clearly point at a problem with the regexp bytecode array or regexp interpreter dispatch, specifically dispatch seems to jump to an invalid address (we use the computed goto extension for interpreter dispatch).<span class="line"><!---->- The symptoms quite clearly point at a problem with the regexp bytecode array or regexp interpreter dispatch, specifically dispatch seems to jump to an invalid address (we use the computed goto extension for interpreter dispatch).<!----></span><br>- This can happen either because the read bytecode is invalid (the bytecode array may be corrupted, may have moved, we may read OOB, or may not be a bytecode array at all); or because ASAN somehow interferes with the computed goto extension. The latter is not an academic possibility, we've seen crashes related due to addtl requirements on registers from ASAN in the past.<span class="line"><!---->- This can happen either because the read bytecode is invalid (the bytecode array may be corrupted, may have moved, we may read OOB, or may not be a bytecode array at all); or because ASAN somehow interferes with the computed goto extension. The latter is not an academic possibility, we've seen crashes related due to addtl requirements on registers from ASAN in the past.<!----></span><br>- Unfortunately I haven't managed to debug this properly yet. On my linux laptop, I get neither an ASAN report, nor does gdb break on the segv. On my Windows VM, after jumping through many hoops, I do get symbolized ASAN reports - but the crash is super-flaky and I know nothing about debugging chromium with windbg. Plus the VM is severely resource-constrained and I can't compile custom builds there.<span class="line"><!---->- Unfortunately I haven't managed to debug this properly yet. On my linux laptop, I get neither an ASAN report, nor does gdb break on the segv. On my Windows VM, after jumping through many hoops, I do get symbolized ASAN reports - but the crash is super-flaky and I know nothing about debugging chromium with windbg. Plus the VM is severely resource-constrained and I can't compile custom builds there.<!----></span><br>- Next steps: attempt to repro on a non-ASAN build.<span class="line"><!---->- Next steps: attempt to repro on a non-ASAN build.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Nov 3, 2021, 9:39 AM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        Tracing isolate creation and flag values suggests something is altering flag values after the Isolate has started:<span class="line"><!---->Tracing isolate creation and flag values suggests something is altering flag values after the Isolate has started:<!----></span><br><br>Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e2b10 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e2b10 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e24d0 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e24d0 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x7fe744008d50 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x7fe744008d50 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x7fe70800d570 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x7fe70800d570 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<!----></span><br>[...]<span class="line"><!---->[...]<!----></span><br>isolate 0x55614d0e2b10  // Immediately prior to the DCHECK failure.<span class="line"><!---->isolate 0x55614d0e2b10  // Immediately prior to the DCHECK failure.<!----></span><br><br>Note isolate 0x55614d0e2b10 starts with --regexp-interpret-all unset but has the flag set prior to the crash.<span class="line"><!---->Note isolate 0x55614d0e2b10 starts with --regexp-interpret-all unset but has the flag set prior to the crash.<!----></span><br><br>It looks like chrome is misusing V8 by starting multiple isolates with different jitless configs in the same process. I vaguely recall hearing related chatter in recent months, gotta do some research.<span class="line"><!---->It looks like chrome is misusing V8 by starting multiple isolates with different jitless configs in the same process. I vaguely recall hearing related chatter in recent months, gotta do some research.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        jgruber@:<span class="line"><!---->jgruber@:<!----></span><br>- is it possible that you start a V8 isolate with --jitless in a renderer process?<span class="line"><!---->- is it possible that you start a V8 isolate with --jitless in a renderer process?<!----></span><br>Yes. The worklet runs in a renderer process (behind a runtime enabled flag). See<span class="line"><!---->Yes. The worklet runs in a renderer process (behind a runtime enabled flag). See<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crrev.com/c/3093127<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/c/3093127"><!---->crrev.com/c/3093127<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>crrev.com/c/3102525<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/c/3102525"><!---->crrev.com/c/3102525<!----></a><br>- Is shared_storage_worklet hidden behind --enable-blink-test-features?<span class="line"><!---->- Is shared_storage_worklet hidden behind --enable-blink-test-features?<!----></span><br>Yes. The RuntimeEnabledFeature is "SharedStorageAPI" and is currently in "test" status.<span class="line"><!---->Yes. The RuntimeEnabledFeature is "SharedStorageAPI" and is currently in "test" status.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 39<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1262676#c39">Comment 39<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="Last visit > 30 days ago" hidden="">schedule</i>

        #38: Thanks, that confirms my suspicions. Since v8 flags are process-wide, it's not valid to spawn multiple isolates with different flags in the same process. For --jitless and friends (e.g. --regexp-interpret-all) it's especially problematic. I suspect the second bug report with different symptoms (<span class="line"><!---->#38: Thanks, that confirms my suspicions. Since v8 flags are process-wide, it's not valid to spawn multiple isolates with different flags in the same process. For --jitless and friends (e.g. --regexp-interpret-all) it's especially problematic. I suspect the second bug report with different symptoms (<!----></span>crbug.com/1264813<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1264813" title="AddressSanitizer: access-violation on unknown address 0x7ed000084040"><!---->crbug.com/1264813<!----></a>) may have the same root cause.<span class="line"><!---->) may have the same root cause.<!----></span><br><br>1) Since SharedStorageAPI is *not* on by default, there is currently no direct user-visible impact.<span class="line"><!---->1) Since SharedStorageAPI is *not* on by default, there is currently no direct user-visible impact.<!----></span><br><br>2) SharedStorageAPI is currently spawns V8 isolates in a way that interferes with other V8 isolates in the same renderer process and will lead to all kinds of hard-to-debug followup errors. The solution is to not spawn SharedStorageAPI isolates with custom flags (-> remove --jitless).<span class="line"><!---->2) SharedStorageAPI is currently spawns V8 isolates in a way that interferes with other V8 isolates in the same renderer process and will lead to all kinds of hard-to-debug followup errors. The solution is to not spawn SharedStorageAPI isolates with custom flags (-&gt; remove --jitless).<!----></span><br><br>3) For the V8 side, two potential work items are in <span class="line"><!---->3) For the V8 side, two potential work items are in <!----></span>#c34<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c34"><!---->#c34<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>yaoxia@ I'm reassigning to you for point 2) above.<span class="line"><!---->yaoxia@ I'm reassigning to you for point 2) above.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I'm still having difficulty reproducing this in a stable, debuggable way. To summarize findings so far:<span class="line"><!---->I'm still having difficulty reproducing this in a stable, debuggable way. To summarize findings so far:<!----></span><br><br>- There appear to be two different crashes, see the backtraces in <span class="line"><!---->- There appear to be two different crashes, see the backtraces in <!----></span>#c15<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c15"><!---->#c15<!----></a> (crash in irregexp) and in <span class="line"><!----> (crash in irregexp) and in <!----></span>#c14<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c14"><!---->#c14<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>#c16<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c16"><!---->#c16<!----></a> (something else). I've only investigated the former in this bug report.<span class="line"><!----> (something else). I've only investigated the former in this bug report.<!----></span><br>- Crashes are reproduced by clicking HavTest and refreshing. Sometimes the crash seems to reproduce easily, at other times it can take many attempts. Due to memory pressure? Due to cache states? It seems to help to change window focus before refreshing the page.<span class="line"><!---->- Crashes are reproduced by clicking HavTest and refreshing. Sometimes the crash seems to reproduce easily, at other times it can take many attempts. Due to memory pressure? Due to cache states? It seems to help to change window focus before refreshing the page.<!----></span><br>- I attempted to bisect but the crash is too flaky.<span class="line"><!---->- I attempted to bisect but the crash is too flaky.<!----></span><br>- The symptoms quite clearly point at a problem with the regexp bytecode array or regexp interpreter dispatch, specifically dispatch seems to jump to an invalid address (we use the computed goto extension for interpreter dispatch).<span class="line"><!---->- The symptoms quite clearly point at a problem with the regexp bytecode array or regexp interpreter dispatch, specifically dispatch seems to jump to an invalid address (we use the computed goto extension for interpreter dispatch).<!----></span><br>- This can happen either because the read bytecode is invalid (the bytecode array may be corrupted, may have moved, we may read OOB, or may not be a bytecode array at all); or because ASAN somehow interferes with the computed goto extension. The latter is not an academic possibility, we've seen crashes related due to addtl requirements on registers from ASAN in the past.<span class="line"><!---->- This can happen either because the read bytecode is invalid (the bytecode array may be corrupted, may have moved, we may read OOB, or may not be a bytecode array at all); or because ASAN somehow interferes with the computed goto extension. The latter is not an academic possibility, we've seen crashes related due to addtl requirements on registers from ASAN in the past.<!----></span><br>- Unfortunately I haven't managed to debug this properly yet. On my linux laptop, I get neither an ASAN report, nor does gdb break on the segv. On my Windows VM, after jumping through many hoops, I do get symbolized ASAN reports - but the crash is super-flaky and I know nothing about debugging chromium with windbg. Plus the VM is severely resource-constrained and I can't compile custom builds there.<span class="line"><!---->- Unfortunately I haven't managed to debug this properly yet. On my linux laptop, I get neither an ASAN report, nor does gdb break on the segv. On my Windows VM, after jumping through many hoops, I do get symbolized ASAN reports - but the crash is super-flaky and I know nothing about debugging chromium with windbg. Plus the VM is severely resource-constrained and I can't compile custom builds there.<!----></span><br>- Next steps: attempt to repro on a non-ASAN build.<span class="line"><!---->- Next steps: attempt to repro on a non-ASAN build.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Tracing isolate creation and flag values suggests something is altering flag values after the Isolate has started:<span class="line"><!---->Tracing isolate creation and flag values suggests something is altering flag values after the Isolate has started:<!----></span><br><br>Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e2b10 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e2b10 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e24d0 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e24d0 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x7fe744008d50 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x7fe744008d50 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x7fe70800d570 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x7fe70800d570 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<!----></span><br>[...]<span class="line"><!---->[...]<!----></span><br>isolate 0x55614d0e2b10  // Immediately prior to the DCHECK failure.<span class="line"><!---->isolate 0x55614d0e2b10  // Immediately prior to the DCHECK failure.<!----></span><br><br>Note isolate 0x55614d0e2b10 starts with --regexp-interpret-all unset but has the flag set prior to the crash.<span class="line"><!---->Note isolate 0x55614d0e2b10 starts with --regexp-interpret-all unset but has the flag set prior to the crash.<!----></span><br><br>It looks like chrome is misusing V8 by starting multiple isolates with different jitless configs in the same process. I vaguely recall hearing related chatter in recent months, gotta do some research.<span class="line"><!---->It looks like chrome is misusing V8 by starting multiple isolates with different jitless configs in the same process. I vaguely recall hearing related chatter in recent months, gotta do some research.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Owner:<strong><!---->Owner:</strong>
          
          yaoxia@chromium.org
          
          <br>
        
          Components:<strong><!---->Components:</strong>
          
          Blink>JavaScript
          
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Owner:</strong>
          
          yaoxia@chromium.org

        <!---->

          Blink&gt;JavaScript
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        #38: Thanks, that confirms my suspicions. Since v8 flags are process-wide, it's not valid to spawn multiple isolates with different flags in the same process. For --jitless and friends (e.g. --regexp-interpret-all) it's especially problematic. I suspect the second bug report with different symptoms (<span class="line"><!---->#38: Thanks, that confirms my suspicions. Since v8 flags are process-wide, it's not valid to spawn multiple isolates with different flags in the same process. For --jitless and friends (e.g. --regexp-interpret-all) it's especially problematic. I suspect the second bug report with different symptoms (<!----></span>crbug.com/1264813<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1264813" title="AddressSanitizer: access-violation on unknown address 0x7ed000084040"><!---->crbug.com/1264813<!----></a>) may have the same root cause.<span class="line"><!---->) may have the same root cause.<!----></span><br><br>1) Since SharedStorageAPI is *not* on by default, there is currently no direct user-visible impact.<span class="line"><!---->1) Since SharedStorageAPI is *not* on by default, there is currently no direct user-visible impact.<!----></span><br><br>2) SharedStorageAPI is currently spawns V8 isolates in a way that interferes with other V8 isolates in the same renderer process and will lead to all kinds of hard-to-debug followup errors. The solution is to not spawn SharedStorageAPI isolates with custom flags (-> remove --jitless).<span class="line"><!---->2) SharedStorageAPI is currently spawns V8 isolates in a way that interferes with other V8 isolates in the same renderer process and will lead to all kinds of hard-to-debug followup errors. The solution is to not spawn SharedStorageAPI isolates with custom flags (-&gt; remove --jitless).<!----></span><br><br>3) For the V8 side, two potential work items are in <span class="line"><!---->3) For the V8 side, two potential work items are in <!----></span>#c34<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c34"><!---->#c34<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>yaoxia@ I'm reassigning to you for point 2) above.<span class="line"><!---->yaoxia@ I'm reassigning to you for point 2) above.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>
    
      
    <mr-comment headinglevel="2"></mr-comment>
      
      
      
        
          Comment 40<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1262676#c40">Comment 40<!----></a>

        Merge review required: M97 is already shipping to beta.<span class="line"><!---->Merge review required: M97 is already shipping to beta.<!----></span><br><br>Please answer the following questions so that we can safely process your merge request:<span class="line"><!---->Please answer the following questions so that we can safely process your merge request:<!----></span><br>1.         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users.         I'm still having difficulty reproducing this in a stable, debuggable way. To summarize findings so far:<span class="line"><!---->I'm still having difficulty reproducing this in a stable, debuggable way. To summarize findings so far:<!----></span><br><br>- There appear to be two different crashes, see the backtraces in <span class="line"><!---->- There appear to be two different crashes, see the backtraces in <!----></span>#c15<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c15"><!---->#c15<!----></a> (crash in irregexp) and in <span class="line"><!----> (crash in irregexp) and in <!----></span>#c14<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c14"><!---->#c14<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>#c16<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c16"><!---->#c16<!----></a> (something else). I've only investigated the former in this bug report.<span class="line"><!----> (something else). I've only investigated the former in this bug report.<!----></span><br>- Crashes are reproduced by clicking HavTest and refreshing. Sometimes the crash seems to reproduce easily, at other times it can take many attempts. Due to memory pressure? Due to cache states? It seems to help to change window focus before refreshing the page.<span class="line"><!---->- Crashes are reproduced by clicking HavTest and refreshing. Sometimes the crash seems to reproduce easily, at other times it can take many attempts. Due to memory pressure? Due to cache states? It seems to help to change window focus before refreshing the page.<!----></span><br>- I attempted to bisect but the crash is too flaky.<span class="line"><!---->- I attempted to bisect but the crash is too flaky.<!----></span><br>- The symptoms quite clearly point at a problem with the regexp bytecode array or regexp interpreter dispatch, specifically dispatch seems to jump to an invalid address (we use the computed goto extension for interpreter dispatch).<span class="line"><!---->- The symptoms quite clearly point at a problem with the regexp bytecode array or regexp interpreter dispatch, specifically dispatch seems to jump to an invalid address (we use the computed goto extension for interpreter dispatch).<!----></span><br>- This can happen either because the read bytecode is invalid (the bytecode array may be corrupted, may have moved, we may read OOB, or may not be a bytecode array at all); or because ASAN somehow interferes with the computed goto extension. The latter is not an academic possibility, we've seen crashes related due to addtl requirements on registers from ASAN in the past.<span class="line"><!---->- This can happen either because the read bytecode is invalid (the bytecode array may be corrupted, may have moved, we may read OOB, or may not be a bytecode array at all); or because ASAN somehow interferes with the computed goto extension. The latter is not an academic possibility, we've seen crashes related due to addtl requirements on registers from ASAN in the past.<!----></span><br>- Unfortunately I haven't managed to debug this properly yet. On my linux laptop, I get neither an ASAN report, nor does gdb break on the segv. On my Windows VM, after jumping through many hoops, I do get symbolized ASAN reports - but the crash is super-flaky and I know nothing about debugging chromium with windbg. Plus the VM is severely resource-constrained and I can't compile custom builds there.<span class="line"><!---->- Unfortunately I haven't managed to debug this properly yet. On my linux laptop, I get neither an ASAN report, nor does gdb break on the segv. On my Windows VM, after jumping through many hoops, I do get symbolized ASAN reports - but the crash is super-flaky and I know nothing about debugging chromium with windbg. Plus the VM is severely resource-constrained and I can't compile custom builds there.<!----></span><br>- Next steps: attempt to repro on a non-ASAN build.<span class="line"><!---->- Next steps: attempt to repro on a non-ASAN build.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Tracing isolate creation and flag values suggests something is altering flag values after the Isolate has started:<span class="line"><!---->Tracing isolate creation and flag values suggests something is altering flag values after the Isolate has started:<!----></span><br><br>Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e2b10 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e2b10 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e24d0 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e24d0 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x7fe744008d50 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x7fe744008d50 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x7fe70800d570 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x7fe70800d570 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<!----></span><br>[...]<span class="line"><!---->[...]<!----></span><br>isolate 0x55614d0e2b10  // Immediately prior to the DCHECK failure.<span class="line"><!---->isolate 0x55614d0e2b10  // Immediately prior to the DCHECK failure.<!----></span><br><br>Note isolate 0x55614d0e2b10 starts with --regexp-interpret-all unset but has the flag set prior to the crash.<span class="line"><!---->Note isolate 0x55614d0e2b10 starts with --regexp-interpret-all unset but has the flag set prior to the crash.<!----></span><br><br>It looks like chrome is misusing V8 by starting multiple isolates with different jitless configs in the same process. I vaguely recall hearing related chatter in recent months, gotta do some research.<span class="line"><!---->It looks like chrome is misusing V8 by starting multiple isolates with different jitless configs in the same process. I vaguely recall hearing related chatter in recent months, gotta do some research.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        #38: Thanks, that confirms my suspicions. Since v8 flags are process-wide, it's not valid to spawn multiple isolates with different flags in the same process. For --jitless and friends (e.g. --regexp-interpret-all) it's especially problematic. I suspect the second bug report with different symptoms (<span class="line"><!---->#38: Thanks, that confirms my suspicions. Since v8 flags are process-wide, it's not valid to spawn multiple isolates with different flags in the same process. For --jitless and friends (e.g. --regexp-interpret-all) it's especially problematic. I suspect the second bug report with different symptoms (<!----></span>crbug.com/1264813<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1264813" title="AddressSanitizer: access-violation on unknown address 0x7ed000084040"><!---->crbug.com/1264813<!----></a>) may have the same root cause.<span class="line"><!---->) may have the same root cause.<!----></span><br><br>1) Since SharedStorageAPI is *not* on by default, there is currently no direct user-visible impact.<span class="line"><!---->1) Since SharedStorageAPI is *not* on by default, there is currently no direct user-visible impact.<!----></span><br><br>2) SharedStorageAPI is currently spawns V8 isolates in a way that interferes with other V8 isolates in the same renderer process and will lead to all kinds of hard-to-debug followup errors. The solution is to not spawn SharedStorageAPI isolates with custom flags (-> remove --jitless).<span class="line"><!---->2) SharedStorageAPI is currently spawns V8 isolates in a way that interferes with other V8 isolates in the same renderer process and will lead to all kinds of hard-to-debug followup errors. The solution is to not spawn SharedStorageAPI isolates with custom flags (-&gt; remove --jitless).<!----></span><br><br>3) For the V8 side, two potential work items are in <span class="line"><!---->3) For the V8 side, two potential work items are in <!----></span>#c34<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c34"><!---->#c34<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>yaoxia@ I'm reassigning to you for point 2) above.<span class="line"><!---->yaoxia@ I'm reassigning to you for point 2) above.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

sanity check for unchanged jitless flags<!----></span><br>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>> V8 flags in general should not change in a process after the<span class="line"><!---->&gt; V8 flags in general should not change in a process after the<!----></span><br>> first Isolate has been initialized. --jitless and related flags<span class="line"><!---->&gt; first Isolate has been initialized. --jitless and related flags<!----></span><br>> especially sensitive to this, so we introduce a dedicated check<span class="line"><!---->&gt; especially sensitive to this, so we introduce a dedicated check<!----></span><br>> just for them.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; just for them.<!----></span><br>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>> <span class="line"><!---->&gt;         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        - We're in the interpreter (--regexp-interpret-all may help to repro).<span class="line"><!---->- We're in the interpreter (--regexp-interpret-all may help to repro).<!----></span><br>- Runtime_RegExpExecTreatMatchAtEndAsFailure in the backtrace tells us we're in RegExp.p.split; in the repro there are only 4 such calls:<span class="line"><!---->- Runtime_RegExpExecTreatMatchAtEndAsFailure in the backtrace tells us we're in RegExp.p.split; in the repro there are only 4 such calls:<!----></span><br><br>var substitution_re = /\$\{([^ }]*)\}/g;<span class="line"><!---->var substitution_re = /\$\{([^ }]*)\}/g;<!----></span><br>var components = input.split(substitution_re);<span class="line"><!---->var components = input.split(substitution_re);<!----></span><br><br>var lines = stack.split("\n");<span class="line"><!---->var lines = stack.split("\n");<!----></span><br><br>var components = name.split(".");<span class="line"><!---->var components = name.split(".");<!----></span><br><br>output_location = assert.stack.split("\n", 1)<span class="line"><!---->output_location = assert.stack.split("\n", 1)<!----></span><br><br>- The flaky repro & OOB read could be a symptom of the GC moving the bytecode array without irregexp updating its pointers.<span class="line"><!---->- The flaky repro &amp; OOB read could be a symptom of the GC moving the bytecode array without irregexp updating its pointers.<!----></span><br>- Or something goes wrong during bytecode interpretation causing us to read OOB.<span class="line"><!---->- Or something goes wrong during bytecode interpretation causing us to read OOB.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I'm still having difficulty reproducing this in a stable, debuggable way. To summarize findings so far:<span class="line"><!---->I'm still having difficulty reproducing this in a stable, debuggable way. To summarize findings so far:<!----></span><br><br>- There appear to be two different crashes, see the backtraces in <span class="line"><!---->- There appear to be two different crashes, see the backtraces in <!----></span>#c15<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c15"><!---->#c15<!----></a> (crash in irregexp) and in <span class="line"><!----> (crash in irregexp) and in <!----></span>#c14<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c14"><!---->#c14<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>#c16<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c16"><!---->#c16<!----></a> (something else). I've only investigated the former in this bug report.<span class="line"><!----> (something else). I've only investigated the former in this bug report.<!----></span><br>- Crashes are reproduced by clicking HavTest and refreshing. Sometimes the crash seems to reproduce easily, at other times it can take many attempts. Due to memory pressure? Due to cache states? It seems to help to change window focus before refreshing the page.<span class="line"><!---->- Crashes are reproduced by clicking HavTest and refreshing. Sometimes the crash seems to reproduce easily, at other times it can take many attempts. Due to memory pressure? Due to cache states? It seems to help to change window focus before refreshing the page.<!----></span><br>- I attempted to bisect but the crash is too flaky.<span class="line"><!---->- I attempted to bisect but the crash is too flaky.<!----></span><br>- The symptoms quite clearly point at a problem with the regexp bytecode array or regexp interpreter dispatch, specifically dispatch seems to jump to an invalid address (we use the computed goto extension for interpreter dispatch).<span class="line"><!---->- The symptoms quite clearly point at a problem with the regexp bytecode array or regexp interpreter dispatch, specifically dispatch seems to jump to an invalid address (we use the computed goto extension for interpreter dispatch).<!----></span><br>- This can happen either because the read bytecode is invalid (the bytecode array may be corrupted, may have moved, we may read OOB, or may not be a bytecode array at all); or because ASAN somehow interferes with the computed goto extension. The latter is not an academic possibility, we've seen crashes related due to addtl requirements on registers from ASAN in the past.<span class="line"><!---->- This can happen either because the read bytecode is invalid (the bytecode array may be corrupted, may have moved, we may read OOB, or may not be a bytecode array at all); or because ASAN somehow interferes with the computed goto extension. The latter is not an academic possibility, we've seen crashes related due to addtl requirements on registers from ASAN in the past.<!----></span><br>- Unfortunately I haven't managed to debug this properly yet. On my linux laptop, I get neither an ASAN report, nor does gdb break on the segv. On my Windows VM, after jumping through many hoops, I do get symbolized ASAN reports - but the crash is super-flaky and I know nothing about debugging chromium with windbg. Plus the VM is severely resource-constrained and I can't compile custom builds there.<span class="line"><!---->- Unfortunately I haven't managed to debug this properly yet. On my linux laptop, I get neither an ASAN report, nor does gdb break on the segv. On my Windows VM, after jumping through many hoops, I do get symbolized ASAN reports - but the crash is super-flaky and I know nothing about debugging chromium with windbg. Plus the VM is severely resource-constrained and I can't compile custom builds there.<!----></span><br>- Next steps: attempt to repro on a non-ASAN build.<span class="line"><!---->- Next steps: attempt to repro on a non-ASAN build.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The optdebug build fails with<span class="line"><!---->The optdebug build fails with<!----></span><br><br># Fatal error in ../../v8/src/regexp/regexp.cc, line 448<span class="line"><!----># Fatal error in ../../v8/src/regexp/regexp.cc, line 448<!----></span><br># Debug check failed: FLAG_regexp_interpret_all implies bytecode.IsByteArray().<span class="line"><!----># Debug check failed: FLAG_regexp_interpret_all implies bytecode.IsByteArray().<!----></span><br><br>despite the FLAG_regexp_interpret_all not being set. This can happen in a jitless isolate (e.g. pdfium); or something is corrupting the flag value.<span class="line"><!---->despite the FLAG_regexp_interpret_all not being set.         Tracing isolate creation and flag values suggests something is altering flag values after the Isolate has started:<span class="line"><!---->Tracing isolate creation and flag values suggests something is altering flag values after the Isolate has started:<!----></span><br><br>Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e2b10 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e2b10 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e24d0 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x55614d0e24d0 --jitless 0 --regexp-interpret-all 0<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x7fe744008d50 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x7fe744008d50 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<!----></span><br>Isolate::Init 0x7fe70800d570 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<span class="line"><!---->Isolate::Init 0x7fe70800d570 --jitless 1 --regexp-interpret-all 1<!----></span><br>[...]<span class="line"><!---->[...]<!----></span><br>isolate 0x55614d0e2b10  // Immediately prior to the DCHECK failure.<span class="line"><!---->isolate 0x55614d0e2b10  // Immediately prior to the DCHECK failure.<!----></span><br><br>Note isolate 0x55614d0e2b10 starts with --regexp-interpret-all unset but has the flag set prior to the crash.<span class="line"><!---->Note isolate 0x55614d0e2b10 starts with --regexp-interpret-all unset but has the flag set prior to the crash.<!----></span><br><br>It looks like chrome is misusing V8 by starting multiple isolates with different jitless configs in the same process. I vaguely recall hearing related chatter in recent months, gotta do some research.<span class="line"><!---->It looks like chrome is misusing V8 by starting multiple isolates with different jitless configs in the same process. I vaguely recall hearing related chatter in recent months, gotta do some research.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        #38: Thanks, that confirms my suspicions. Since v8 flags are process-wide, it's not valid to spawn multiple isolates with different flags in the same process. For --jitless and friends (e.g. --regexp-interpret-all) it's especially problematic. I suspect the second bug report with different symptoms (<span class="line"><!---->#38: Thanks, that confirms my suspicions. Since v8 flags are process-wide, it's not valid to spawn multiple isolates with different flags in the same process. For --jitless and friends (e.g. --regexp-interpret-all) it's especially problematic. I suspect the second bug report with different symptoms (<!----></span>crbug.com/1264813<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1264813" title="AddressSanitizer: access-violation on unknown address 0x7ed000084040"><!---->crbug.com/1264813<!----></a>) may have the same root cause.<span class="line"><!---->) may have the same root cause.<!----></span><br><br>1) Since SharedStorageAPI is *not* on by default, there is currently no direct user-visible impact.<span class="line"><!---->1) Since SharedStorageAPI is *not* on by default, there is currently no direct user-visible impact.<!----></span><br><br>2) SharedStorageAPI is currently spawns V8 isolates in a way that interferes with other V8 isolates in the same renderer process and will lead to all kinds of hard-to-debug followup errors. The solution is to not spawn SharedStorageAPI isolates with custom flags (-> remove --jitless).<span class="line"><!---->2) SharedStorageAPI is currently spawns V8 isolates in a way that interferes with other V8 isolates in the same renderer process and will lead to all kinds of hard-to-debug followup errors. The solution is to not spawn SharedStorageAPI isolates with custom flags (-&gt; remove --jitless).<!----></span><br><br>3) For the V8 side, two potential work items are in <span class="line"><!---->3) For the V8 side, two potential work items are in <!----></span>#c34<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c34"><!---->#c34<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br><br>yaoxia@ I'm reassigning to you for point 2) above.<span class="line"><!---->yaoxia@ I'm reassigning to you for point 2) above.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

    <mr-autocomplete vocabularyname="project" for="targetProjectInput" role="listbox" id="chops-autocomplete-1"><!---->
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement. 
      <input id="checkbox" type="checkbox">

      </label>

            </tr>
          <!---->
        </tbody></table>

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
<script type="text/javascript" nonce="">
 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
</script>
